sen.j: 日本の官制（にほんのかんせい）では、日本の前近代､とくに律令制期の廃止された統治機構について概観する。
sen.e: Bureaucratic system in Japan gives an overview of the governance in the pre-modern period, especially under ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) which was abolished.

In this portion, an overview of the governance in pre-modern times will be given, especially under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) which was abolished.

In this portion, an overview of the governance in pre-modern times will be given, especially under the ritsuryo system (a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code) which was abolished.

sen.j: なお近代の官制は近代日本の官制を､現在の官制については日本の国家機関を参照。
sen.e: Refer to the modern Japanese bureaucratic system for modern administrative system, and the Japanese state institution for current administrative system, respectively.

sen.j: ヤマト王権の形成期、「カバネ（カバネ）」と呼ばれる血縁集団から「氏（ウジ）」と呼ばれる同族集団が現れ、この「氏」や「部（ベ）」と呼ばれる職能集団が、それぞれの勢力や能力によって王権内の仕事を分掌した。
sen.e: In the formative period of Yamato Dynasty, peer groups called 'uji' appeared from kin groups called 'kabane', and the professional groups called 'uji' or 'be' took charge of duties according to their power and ability.

In the formative period of the Yamato Dynasty, peer groups called 'uji' appeared from kin groups called 'kabane', and professional groups called 'uji' or 'be' took charge of duties according to their power and ability.

In the formative period of the Yamato Dynasty, clans called 'uji' appeared from consanguineous groups called 'kabane,' and such professional groups called 'uji' or 'be' took charge of duties according to their power and ability.
sen.cmt: 左記のとおりに変更しました。

sen.j: 「氏」や「部」は各々、土地と人民を所有・支配した（部民制）。
sen.e: Each 'uji' and 'be' possessed and ruled their land and people (the system of Bemin who belonged to Yamato dynasty)).
Each 'uji' and 'be' possessed and ruled their land and people (the system of Bemin who belonged to Yamato dynasty)).
Each 'uji' and 'be' possessed and ruled their land and people (the system of bemin, the people in subordinate position).

sen.j: 次第に、「姓」・「氏」や「部」は、王権によって序列化・統制され、私的な集団から公的な制度へと編成されて行く。
sen.e: Kabane', 'uji', and 'be' were gradually graded and controlled by the royal authority, and the private groups were organized in a public system.
Kabane', 'uji', and 'be' were gradually graded and controlled by the royal authority, and private groups were organized in a public system.
The dynasty gradually made 'kabane,' 'uji,' and 'be' incorporated into a hierarchy, and these private groups were organized in a public system.
sen.cmt: 左記のとおりに変更しました。カンマの位置を調整

sen.j: （→氏姓制度、八色の姓）
sen.e: (The system of clans and hereditary titles, Yakusa no Kabane (the eight honorary titles)).

sen.j: 一方、皇族（大王 (ヤマト王権)の一族）を中心とする支配体制を強化し、血縁や勢力にとらわれない人材登用を進めるため、官位（冠位）の制度（官職と位階を関連づける制度）も取り入れられる。
sen.e: An official rank (cap rank) system which associated government post with court rank was also adopted to consolidate the power of Imperial families (a clan of okimi (Yamato Dynasty) and to take talented people into government service free from blood relations and influence.

An official rank (cap rank) system whereby an associated government post with court rank was also adopted to consolidate the power of the Imperial families (a clan of okimi (Yamato Dynasty) and to take talented people into government service free from blood relations and influence.

The official rank (cap rank) system (the system where a government post was associated with a court rank) was also adopted in order to consolidate the government headed by the imperial families (a clan of okimi [Yamato Dynasty]) and to appoint talented people into government service free from blood relations and influence.

sen.j: 603年（推古天皇11年）、聖徳太子が制定した冠位十二階は、その嚆矢である。
sen.e: Kan I junikai (twelve grades of cap rank) which was enacted by Prince Shotoku in 603 was the first instance.

sen.j: この官位の制度は、冠位十二階から律令による官位制まで、数度の変遷がある（冠位・官位制度の変遷）。
sen.e: This official rank system changed several times from Kan I junikai to the official rank system based on ritsuryo.
This official rank system changed several times from the twelve graded Kan I junikai to the official rank system based on the ritsuryo system.
This court rank system changed several times from the twelve court rank system of 603 to the system of and official court ranks based on the ritsuryo code.

sen.j: 氏姓制度と官位制、および職掌を体系的に整備したのが律令制である。
sen.e: Ritsuryo system was systematically developed from the system of clans and hereditary titles, official rank system, and official duties.
The Ritsuryo system was systematically developed from a system of clans and hereditary titles, official rank system, and official duties.

sen.j: 668年（天智天皇8年）に最初の「令（りょう）」である近江令が制定され、689年（持統天皇3年）の飛鳥浄御原令において初めて体系化されたといわれている。
sen.e: The first 'Ryo'(administrative code), Omi-Ryo was enacted in 668, and Asuka Kiyomihara Code enacted in 689 is said to be the first systematized Ryo.
The first 'Ryo'(administrative code), Omi-Ryo was enacted in 668, and Asuka Kiyomihara Code enacted in 689 is said to have been the first systematized Ryo.

sen.j: 701年（大宝 (日本)元年）に成立した大宝律令は、その集大成となった。

sen.j: 中央官制は、二官八省を基本とする体制である。
sen.e: Central government bureaucratic system was an organization based on two departments and eight ministries.
The Central government bureaucratic system was an organization based on two departments and eight ministries.
The Central government bureaucratic system was an organization based on two departments and eight ministries.

sen.j: 君主である天皇の下に、朝廷の祭祀を担当する神祇官と国政を統括する太政官が置かれ（二官）、太政官の下に実際の行政を分担する八省が置かれた。
sen.e: Under the emperor as a sovereign ruler, Jingikan (officer of the institution for dedicating to religious ceremony) and Daijokan (Grand Council of State) were established and under the Daijokan, eight ministries were set up to take charge of the actual administration.

sen.e: Other than the two departments and eight ministries, Danjodai (Board of Censors) which inspected administrative organization and Efu (a palace guard) were established under emperor's direct control. (Two departments, eight ministries, one board of censor and five palace guards in total).

sen.j: 中国の律令制が皇帝にすべての権限を集めて三省（中書省・門下省・尚書省）がこれを補佐する体制であるのに対し、日本の律令制では、天皇と各省の間に天皇の代理機能を果たす緩やかな合議体、太政官を置いたことに特徴がある。
sen.e: The ritsuryo system in China concentrated all power in the emperor and three ministries of Secretariat, Chancellery and State Affairs supported the system, but Japanese ritsuryo system was characterized by the establishment of loose consultative body and Daijokan (Grand Council of State) worked as emperor's proxy between the emperor and ministries.

The ritsuryo system in China concentrated all power in the emperor and three ministries of Secretariat, Chancellery and State Affairs which supported the system, but the Japanese ritsuryo system was characterized by the establishment of a loose consultative body and Daijokan (Grand Council of State) which worked as the emperor's proxy between the emperor and ministries.

While the ritsuryo system in China concentrated all power in the emperor, who was supported by three ministries of Secretariat, Chancellery and State Affairs, Japanese ritsuryo system was characterized by the establishment of a loose consultative body, namely Daijokan (Grand Council of State), which worked as the emperor's proxy between the emperor and ministries.

sen.j: またこれとは別に、要地には特別の職（大宰府、京職､摂津職など）が配置された。
sen.e: Apart from that, special Shiki (agency) such as Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region), Kyoshiki (the Capital Bureau), and Settsu Shiki (an agency of Settsu province) were set up at important places.

Apart from that, special Shiki (agency) such as Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region), Kyoshiki (the Capital Bureau), and Settsu Shiki (an agency of Settsu province) were set up at important places.

Apart from that, special Shiki (agency) such as Dazai-fu (local government office in Kyushu region), Kyoshiki (the Capital Bureau), and Settsu Shiki (an agency of Settsu province) were set up at important places.

sen.j: 諸官司には一般に長官（かみ）・次官（すけ）・判官（じょう）・主典（さかん）の四等官が置かれた。
sen.e: There were generally four ranks of government official: Kami (director), Suke (assistant director), Jo (inspector (third highest of the four administrative ranks of the ritsuryo period), and Sakan (secretary (lowest of the four administrative ranks of the ritsuryo period)).

There were generally four ranks of government officials: Kami (director), Suke (assistant director), Jo (inspector (third highest of the four administrative ranks of the ritsuryo period), and Sakan (secretary (lowest of the four administrative ranks of the ritsuryo period)).

There were generally four ranks of government officials: Kami (director, the first rank offical), Suke (assistant director, the second rank official), Jo (inspector, the third rank official), and Sakan (secretary, the lowest rank official).
sen.cmt: 左記のとおりに変更しました。

sen.j: そのほかに各種の品官（ほんかん）（以上は官位相当官）や史生（ししょう）・伴部（ともべ）・使部（しぶ）などの雑任（ぞうにん、下級職員）が所属していた。
sen.e: There were also various Honkan (these are the ranks of the bureaucracy system of the ritsuryo system) and Zonin (lower-ranking government official) such as Shisho (a person doing miscellaneous duties about documents), Tomobe (Servant of the Court administering a group) and Shibe (low rank bureaucrats).

There were also various Honkan (these are the ranks of the bureaucracy system of the ritsuryo system) and Zonin (lower-ranking government official) such as Shisho (a person doing miscellaneous duties about documents), Tomobe (Servant of the Court administering a group) and Shibe (low rank bureaucrats).

Other thant these officials of four ranks, there were also various officall called Honkan as well as Zonin (lower-ranked staffs) such as Shisho (staff in charge of miscellaneous clerical duties), Tomobe (foreman of respective duties) and Shibe (odd-job man).

sen.j: 奉膳と典膳は内膳司のみに存在する。
sen.e: Buzen (the administrator of Imperial Table Office) and Tenzen (suke (assistant director) of naizenshi) existed only in Naizen no tsukasa (Imperial Table Office).
